title: General Motors reaches tentative deal with United Auto Workers
text:
The move brings the company close to ending a month-long strike of almost 50,000 auto workers in the U.S. Both parties confirmed the agreement, which has yet to be finalized, but haven’t disclosed details. Sources familiar with the negotiations said GM’s union members, who are fighting for better pay and benefits in their new contracts, are expected to get raises and bonuses in the deal. (Wall Street Journal)

Talking point: The strike, the biggest for GM since the 1970s, has had substantial impacts on the company and the auto sector. GM has lost more than US$2 billion due to the work stoppage. The company’s Canadian arm temporarily laid off close to 3,000 workers with pay and closed its plants in Oshawa and Ingersoll, Ont. (The latter has since reopened.) GM hasn’t said what long-term impact the strike will have on its business, which is already struggling in Canada. Last November, it cut more than 2,000 jobs at its Oshawa facility; workers at the manufacturer Nemak’s Windsor plant, which predominantly makes parts for GM, are challenging the facility’s planned closure.
